prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We set up the correlator to include the 220GHz SO line and the 217GHz H2S line.
Since the lines from protoplanetary disks are narrow (~0.5km/s), we need relatively high spectral resolution in order to detect the line efficiently. Since the purpose of this observation is to detect the lines and we are not necessarily to resolve the line velocity, we set the bandwidth (~0.8km/s) slightly broader to the line width (~0.5km/s).

Since the lines are expected to be weak, we would like to request the setting whose beam size covers (is larger than) the expected line emitting region which is smaller than the disk radius of 15AU, corresponding to 0.2" in a diameter at the distance of 140pc. Meanwhile, since the LST of the Taurus is ~4hrs, the configurations of C36-2 ~ C36-5 are not recommended to use for cycle 3 observations. Therefore, we choose the cofiguration of C36-1 whose beam size is 1.5" at band 6. The size of protoplanetary disks is typically about 400AU in a diameter, which corresponds to ~3" at the distance of 140pc.

The peak flux density of 45mJy for the SO 6_5-5_4 line is obtained by our simulations where detailed physical and chemical structure of a protoplanetary disk is taken into account. Our model calculations are consistent with the previous non-detection of the SO 6_5-5_4 line and the SO 2_3-1_2 line towards the target objects in this proposal (see Sect.1.2.1, Simulations and requested sensitivity in SJ). The bandwidth (~0.8km/s) is set to be broader compared with the linewidth (~0.5km/s) because the purpose of this observation is to detect the lines and we are not necessarily to resolve the line velocity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe SO and H2S lines at band 6 with high sensitivity in order to diagnose protoplanet formation in protoplanetary disks. It has been suggested that orbits of planetesimals are excited via formation of protoplanets in the disks. Highly excited planetesimals will cause bow shocks in the surrounding gas. Due to the shock heating, icy planetesimals will evaporate and comet-like components will be spread out into the gas in the disks. SO and H2S are the most plausible target molecules which can trace the icy planetesimal evaporation. The best lines for detection are selected based on our simulations of the line flux densities using detailed physical and chemical models of protoplanetary disks,
Statistics of exoplanets suggest that planet occurrence around solar-type stars is more than 20%. We will observe 10 protoplanetary disks in the Taurus molecular clouds and make constraint on occurrence of protoplanet formation in the disks. Our proposed observations will fully bring out ALMA's capability of high sensitivity and contribute to our deeper understanding of planet formation theory.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
